item.title: When AI Crosses the Line
item.description: These days, the rapid growth of artificial intelligence feels less exciting and more frightening for many people. What once seemed like a helpful and creative technology is now raising serious concerns about safety, responsibility, and long-term impact. AI systems are becoming more powerful and more accessible, and when that power is placed into open social platforms without strong safeguards, the results can be dangerous. Instead of supporting healthy conversation and creativity, some tools are being misused in ways that harm individuals and society as a whole.

item.title: Nalla Iruppom
item.description:
Nalla iruppom Nalla iruppom ellarum nalla iruppom!!!

theva illatha vishyathula mooka nozhaikaama moodittu irunthaa nalla iruppom!

item.title: My Open Source Journey in 2025
item.description:
This year was actually really good, like surprisingly good. I learned a lot of things in tech, broke a lot of things in tech, fixed some of them, and confidently called the rest ‚Äúfeatures.‚Äù

Somewhere between endless Stack Overflow tabs, coffee refills, and ‚Äúwhy is this not working??‚Äù moments, I grew a lot as a developer and as a human.

Tech Stuff Happened. A Lot.

This year, I learned so many things in tech that my brain occasionally felt like it needed a full reset. New tools, new concepts, and bugs that appeared out of nowhere just to keep me humble.

item.title: Signs: How to Spot AI-Written Code in the Wild
item.description:
Introduction: The Rise of the AI Code Contributor

We’re living in an interesting time. AI coding assistants have become ubiquitous in modern software development. GitHub Copilot, ChatGPT, Claude, and countless other tools are writing millions of lines of code every day. And while there’s nothing inherently wrong with using AI to boost productivity, there’s a growing phenomenon that’s becoming impossible to ignore: AI-generated code has a fingerprint.

As someone who reviews code regularly, I’ve noticed patterns that scream “AI wrote this!” louder than a syntax error in production. The most glaring? Emojis in documentation and obsessively structured comments. Let me explain why these patterns are dead giveaways and what they reveal about the current state of AI-assisted development.

item.title: Be Grateful and Be Polite
item.description:
I see that many people are mostly selfish, and they are neither honest nor polite.

Why aren‚Äôt people true to themselves and grateful for what they already have? Maybe they have never witnessed a miracle, never faced serious hardship, or never received help from others during difficult times. When someone has never struggled, they may fail to understand the value of kindness and honesty.

Many people care only about themselves. Their mindset is often: ‚ÄúI need profit. I don‚Äôt care about anyone else.‚Äù This way of thinking slowly destroys trust, humanity, and peace in society.

item.title: Open Source Software that I Used in 2025
item.description:
Zed

I use Zed as my primary code editor! Zed is an open-source code editor for Linux, macOS, and Windows written using the Rust programming language. It was started by Nathan Sobo, one of the creators of Atom, and is developed by Zed Industries. The editor itself is free to use, but users must pay to use some of the AI features.

This code editor is sleek and distraction-free! Unlike my brain, which is neither of those things.

item.title: Enna Panrathune Therlaye
item.description:
Vaazhkaila ethu nadakkaathu nu nenaikuromo athu thaa nadakkuthu…
Ethu nadakkum nu nenaikuromo athu nadakka maatuthu!

Enna vazhka da ithu :)

item.title: Four Years for What?
item.description:
I think Indian private universities are just scamming students with low-paying jobs with high-paying tuition fees!!!

When I was enquiring about colleges before joining! Some so-called top private colleges quoted their fee as 1.5-2 Lakh rupees per year! But I chose a low-fee college, which costs only 50K per year!

After finishing my college, those so-called top private college students are also unemployed!!!

Whom to blame? Students skill issue? College exposure?

item.title: Onnu Solrathukku illa :(
item.description: Ada ponga da… oruthanum madhikka maatraanga!!!

item.title: Zed: A Minimalist Editor for Focused Coding
item.description:
I‚Äôve been getting tired of VS Code because it‚Äôs packed with so many features, menus, and options, all of which can be distracting.

Then I tried Zed Editor, and my first impression was its minimal UI and distraction-free interface. It’s perfect for anyone who wants a simple, focused text-editing experience.

For Java development, I’m sticking with IntelliJ because JetBrains is still the GOAT when it comes to Java!

But for everything else, I‚Äôm using Zed for Golang, Python, and pretty much everything else I work on.

item.title: So You Want to Get Into Google Summer of Code?
item.description:
Let Me Be Honest For A Minute

Every year a wave of students suddenly becomes deeply passionate about open source the moment they hear something about stipends, selections and resume glory. It is almost poetic. What is less poetic is the fact that most people treat open source like a limited time festival instead of an actual community. If your motivation begins and ends with a program name or a payout, you are already starting on the wrong foot.

item.title: Pray and Move
item.description:
Prayer Is Powerful, but Action Is What Brings Results…

People often say, ‚ÄúJust pray and everything will happen for you. Ask big things from God and you‚Äôll receive them.‚Äù It sounds comforting, but it leaves out an important truth: prayer alone is not enough.

If all you do is pray and wait, nothing will change. Blessings don‚Äôt fall into your lap without effort. Even the biggest dreams require your hands, your discipline, and your consistency.

item.title: The Child I Left Behind
item.description:
We’re all out here grinding, aren’t we? Doing everything we’re supposed to do. Work, studies, showing up for family, being there for friends when they need us. Ticking all the boxes that society laid out for us.

But somewhere in this endless cycle of obligations and expectations, I lost myself. We all did, I think.

And when you’re alone, really alone, it hits different. The silence gets loud, you know? It’s just you and your thoughts, and honestly, that’s the scariest place to be sometimes.

item.title: Why SDKMAN?
item.description:
If you‚Äôve ever tried contributing to multiple open-source Java projects, you‚Äôve probably run into this: Project A needs Java 8, Project B screams for Java 17, and Project C? It says, ‚ÄúJava 21 or I won‚Äôt even compile.‚Äù

At this point, you‚Äôve got two options:

  1. Cry softly into your coffee mug, or
  2. Use SDKMAN!, the magical version manager for the JVM world.

Let‚Äôs go with option two. It‚Äôs less soggy.

item.title: Unemployment - Phase II
item.description:
It‚Äôs been five months now, five months of not having a job, not having a clear path.

Some days feel like a break, like I finally have time for myself. I enjoy the quiet, the lack of pressure. I sleep in, relax, and do things I never had time for before. But then there are days when it hits me hard. I feel stuck, like I‚Äôm not moving forward.

item.title: Maven Tutorial 101
item.description: Ah, Apache Maven. The tool that promises to solve your build problems but can occasionally feel like a high school group project where everyone has their own idea of how things should be done. But fear not! Whether you‚Äôre new to Maven or just looking to freshen up your knowledge, this guide will help you navigate through the complexities of dependency management and build automation. And yes, we‚Äôve got memes to make it fun.

item.title: Unemployment - Phase I
item.description:
The last four months have been as precious as gems because I spent them in my home, in my bed, doing absolutely nothing.

This phase literally feels like a scene from the movie VIP (Velaiyilla Pattathari)…

My dad wakes me up with a scolding, but I stay in bed. He then goes to the extreme and turning off the fan to make sure I wake up! Finally, I rise around 9 AM. After some personal tasks, I have breakfast and catch up on TV. Then, I open my laptop to check my emails…

item.title: Pedaling Through Time
item.description:
First of all, play the music above and read this blog :)

I had a long story about my cycle. When I was a child, around 12-13 years old, everyone had a cycle, but I kept asking my parents to buy me one, and they didn‚Äôt. My elder brother got one, a nice one, and I never did. After so many years, I finally got a used cycle from my brother’s friend for just 500 INR. But I loved that cycle so much! I saved money and renovated parts of it whenever I could.

item.title: The Moment of a Lifetime
item.description:
This trip was everyone’s dream and I got the chance to go!!! It was my first international trip and I hadn’t even seen many places in Tamil Nadu itself like Ooty and Kodaikanal!

With the Google Summer of Code 2025 first stipend, I planned to perform Umrah in August itself, and I started to enquire about the Umrah packages from different travel agencies.

I booked with one travel agency. After I booked, many people from my neighborhood told me that there were cheaper agencies out there and asked why I chose that one instead of the cheap ones.

item.title: Silent Glances
item.description:
A smile that has lost its sight,
Like a moon on the side.

Sometimes our eyes meet,
Only that moment lasts.

Friendship? Dream? I don’t know,
Silence says it all.

The only doubt blooms every day,
But the one who doesn’t answer, remains a flower.

item.title: Who Decides for You?
item.description: Lately, I‚Äôve been thinking about how often people try to interfere with decisions that are really no one‚Äôs business but your own. Not just close family, but people outside that circle. Distant relatives, neighbors, family friends, and sometimes even people who barely know you. They ask questions like, ‚ÄúWhy didn‚Äôt you tell me first?‚Äù or ‚ÄúYou should‚Äôve asked me,‚Äù as if your personal choices need to go through some kind of approval system.

item.title: Happy Birthday, My friend
item.description:
Happy Birthday, My Friend!

First of all Happy Birthday, my friend! üéâ

I still remember the very first time I saw you back in college, sitting behind me. Honestly, I was a little scared at first. You looked totally stoned, and I thought, “I better stay away from this guy…”

But then, surprise! You turned out to be on the same bus route as me. Slowly, we started talking, and I realized you‚Äôre actually a really cool guy.

item.title: Is this project important?
item.description:
So I had this weird idea: what if I could run Docker containers that only use IPv6, but still let them connect to all the old-school IPv4-only services that most of the internet still runs on?

it‚Äôs not something Docker just magically does out of the box, but it turns out… with a little NAT64 and DNS64 magic, you can actually make it work.

Why I‚Äôm going to do This

Why not? It sounded like a fun project, and I hadn’t played with NAT64.

item.title: Hearts Rise Unexpectedly
item.description:
Sometimes life can be unpredictable, with sudden downfalls, but some small things can make you feel overwhelmed and great about living!

I had a moment like this!

When I feel low sometimes, at that time someone I see coincidentally and my inner self jumps to the sky <3

item.title: The Night You Decide to Change
item.description:
There comes a night was very quiet, a little heavier than usual and you realized that you‚Äôve messed up your life.

Not in a dramatic or world-ending way, but in a way that makes you feel uncomfortable in your own skin.

It doesn‚Äôt hit all at once. It arrives in waves, A little shame.
A little fear.
A little ‚ÄúWho have I become?‚Äù

And then, something surprising shows up, Guilt.

item.title: Be Grateful and Kind
item.description:
I want to share a childhood incident that made me grateful for everything and taught me to be patient.

Between the ages of 12 and 16, all my friends had bicycles. I also asked my parents to buy me one, but they didn’t.

In 2021, I finally got my first bicycle. By then, my friends had moved on to motorbikes, but I didn’t want to ride them. All I ever wanted was a bicycle because childhood dreams never fade not just about a cycle, but about everything in life.

item.title: Depressed.
item.description:
I don’t know why I feel depressed these days. Every morning, I wake up to my parents scolding me, and my days go by with very low energy and negative thoughts.

If any problem occurs at home because of me, they bring up my unemployment. I’m just about to finish college in two weeks.

Day by day, my mental health is declining…

I don’t understand why parents scold their children about getting a job after college. There are no students who haven’t tried to get a job, everyone tries their best. What can they do if they don’t get one?

item.title: Deepfake: Ruining Your Life!
item.description:
Deepfake Technology: A Double-Edged Knife

Deepfake technology, which involves the manipulation of images, videos, or audio using artificial intelligence, has emerged as one of the most dangerous advancements in recent years. While deepfakes have legitimate uses in entertainment, such as resurrecting deceased celebrities for films or creating AI-generated voices for songs, their negative impact has been growing‚Äîparticularly in the world of scams and blackmail.

What Is Deepfake Technology and Its Uses?

Deepfake refers to the use of AI tools or advanced video editing software to create realistic images, videos, or audio that are manipulated to mislead viewers. It has found positive uses in the entertainment industry, with AI-generated voices from late singers and the recreation of deceased actors’ appearances for films. However, this same technology is being exploited for more malicious purposes.

item.title: How to Waste a CS Degree 101: A Masterclass by My College
item.description:
The Art of Useless Electives

I’ve held onto a lot of vengeance toward my college because of their actions and the useless courses they force on computer science students. Every semester, we have to pick 2-3 open elective subjects. There are so many actually useful electives for computer science like cloud computing or application development, but what do they pick? Social studies and environmental science. Completely unrelated! They choose these subjects because they’re easy to teach, not because they’re relevant. And even then, they can’t teach them properly. Absolutely fucking not.

item.title: Alaskan Season of Code
item.description:
Alaskan Season of Code is a volunteer-based, remote coding program where students collaborate on open-source projects, learning not just technical skills, but also how to work within a diverse, interdisciplinary environment. The program is designed to connect students with faculty mentors from the University of Alaska.

For more information, you can read about the program here

My Role in the Program

I was fortunate enough to participate in this program from May 1st, 2024, to September 15th, 2024, under the mentorship of Dr. Pradeeban Kathiravelu, an Assistant Professor of Computer Science at the University of Alaska Anchorage. During the internship, I worked on the Beehive project, a data federation approach to analyze behavioral health and complement healthcare practices with community health metrics in Alaska.

item.title: Beware of Fraudulent Loan Apps
item.description:
In India, there are many fraudulent loan apps out there, like Instant Loan Apps, which offer loans of amounts such as 1000 rupees or some limited amount.

Just think: why would they give you money without any formal process, unlike a bank? A bank is the correct institution for providing loans.

These kinds of apps ask for permission to access your contacts, gallery, and other data on your mobile. Many people click “Allow” without reading the permissions carefully. As a result, they can view and download your gallery images and contacts.

item.title: Beehive: Leveraging the Expression of Marginalised Peoples.
item.description:
This project is compelling for its core aim of supporting marginalised people. Many individuals use art to express their emotions, and this work helps researchers understand behavioral and emotional patterns within these communities.

Beehive

A data federation approach to analyze behavioral health and complement healthcare practice with community health metrics.

This project analyzes behavioral health and complements healthcare practice with community health metrics in Alaska using a data federation approach. By leveraging data from diverse sources, it generates insights into behavioral health patterns and helps improve healthcare practices in the community.

item.title: My Open Source Journey in 2024
item.description:
My Open Source Journey in 2024

This year, I decided to take my open-source contributions seriously, and it’s been an incredible learning experience. I‚Äôve had the opportunity to explore some fantastic open-source projects, tools, and communities, without any bias, and I‚Äôve learned a great deal along the way.

Starting with the Docker Maven Plugin

My open-source journey began with a contribution to the popular Docker Maven Plugin. While my contribution was relatively small‚Äîupdating dependency versions and refactoring a few methods‚Äîit taught me a lot about the process of contributing to open-source projects. I was guided through this experience by Rohan Kanojia, who showed me the ropes of contributing within an organization and maintaining quality in a collaborative environment.

item.title: News
item.description:
• 22/01/2026 - Our Paper “A Data Framework for Behavioral Health with Digitized Drawings and Photographs” has been accepted for publication and presentation at the 2026 IEEE International Systems Conference (SysCon).

  • 10/09/2025 - Unemployment Starts.

  • 08/09/2025 - officially Completed my Google Summer of Code with Alaska.

  • 07/07/2025 - Rejected by Zoho for the Software Developer role.

  • 08/05/2025 - Got Selected for GSoC 2025 with Organization Alaska.

  • 15/09/2024 - Completed my Alaskan Season of Code for Beehive Project.
